prompt: Recite a short, meaningful and inspiring excerpt from the Upanishads.
response:
The Upanishads are ancient Indian texts that explore ultimate truths, including the nature of reality, creation, divinity, knowledge, and liberation. Here is a short yet meaningful and inspiring passage from the Chhandogya Upanishad:
<|qu|>(1) What is never born, never dies—that which was, is and will be—you are that.
(2) My soul dwelt in another world than this; it nourished itself on honey of figs. The boy cried to me, ‘Who are you?’ I replied, ‘I am he who tries not to cry.’ Then the elder boys said to me, ‘Come with us and play.’
(3) I said: ‘Yes, if it can be made clear to me who I am.’ And they said to me, ‘Look into this mirror!’ (4) They took me to a cave full of holes; the boy fit through one of them. The others shut the entrance behind us; it was dark inside.
(5) The elder boys said, ‘Look at us! Who are we? You and your shadow are two; when there is no sun we can’t see either of you.’ (6) Then someone took off his clothes and showed himself naked; they asked if I recognized that being; when I replied No! it went into another cave.
(7) The next person had a strange body; they said, ‘Is this a living thing?’ They asked if I knew what it was; when I replied No! the being went into yet another cave. In this way they led me through all these regions.^{[1]}

Alan Wilson Watts (6 January 1910 – 16 November 1973) was a British-American philosopher who spent most of his life in the United States. He was considered one of the most influential interpreters of Eastern philosophy for the Western world, and helped popularize Zen Buddhism in particular. He also pioneered the integration of Eastern thought into Western psychology and psychiatry.
Watts lived in California for most of his life and taught comparative religion and mysticism at various institutions there, including a stint as professor of mystical literature at the University of Chicago's Pacific Coast campus in Placer County from 1938 to 1945. From 1946 until his death he lived in Mill Valley, north of San Francisco.
He wrote more than two dozen books on philosophy, religion, and psychology. Some of his most popular works include "The Way of Zen," "The Book: On the Taboo Against Knowing Who You Are," "The Joyous Cosmology: The Evolutionary Vision of Henry More," "This Is It: An Essay on Zen Buddhism," and "Psychotherapy East and West."

Jiddu Krishnamurti (1895–1986) was a renowned Indian speaker and writer on spirituality, philosophy, and living in the modern world. Though he received little formal education, he became a close student of both Eastern and Western thoughts, absorbing ideas from philosophers, psychologists, and spiritual teachers—even those who disputed one another. By age twenty-eight—with his guidance sought after by leaders including Rabindranath Tagore, Albert Einstein, T. S. Eliot, Mohandas Gandhi, Kazemir Malevich, Mme. Blavatsky, Thomas Edison, and Oscar Wilde—Krishnamurti became exhausted with the limitations of all tradition and abruptly ended his career as a teacher. Instead, he began what he called a “quest for truth.” With no doctrine to promote, no creed to preach, no institution he led, he set out on a global continent of exploration, lecturing wherever anyone would gather him—at schools, prisons, religious groups, corporate offices—and attracting an enormous following. Some thought he was one of the most important and promising figures in our time, even hoping that he might be “the new Buddha.” Others disliked or scoffed at him. What everyone seemed to notice immediately upon meeting him, however, was his exceptional calmness and humility. Wherever he travelled and whomever he met, Krishnamurti emphasized the need for simplicity and clarity of thought; a direct perception of life as it stood independent of prior beliefs, opinions, or values; an effort to cast aside all conditioning that had previously shaped our self-understanding (what he referred to as “the problem of the ego”), in hopes of discovering instead some deeper personal identity—which some saw as connection with the divine. Eventually Krishnamurti came to reject even that term, “the divine.” Ultimately, his quest led him not to escape from all tradition and learning but rather back into an appreciation for certain Eastern mythologies—while at the same time continuing to seek a very unique balance between what he valued in both East and West. With no doctrine or institution to anoint him, however, Krishnamurti had difficulty sustaining his role as a teacher; by 1945 he announced that he had completed his mission. Since then his collected talks have been widely published, including a twelve-volume edition of The Collected Works of Jiddu Krishnamurti (The Kronos Press, 1978). And certain schools—for example, the Krishnamurti School in India and the Rishi Valley school nearby—have remained open under his influence. In recent decades an international network of organizations known as The Krishnamurti Centers have grown up to sponsor lectures and discussions celebrating what they each understand as his principal insight

Joseph Campbell (March 28, 1904 - October 30, 1987) was a noted American scholar who wrote extensively about comparative mythology and the hero’s journey. His most recognized work is The Hero with a Thousand Faces.
Joseph Campbell’s fame came much later on in his life after the release of George Lucas' movie Star Wars where he served as a consultant and the movie’s basic structure was taken from Campbell’s book “The Hero with a Thousand Faces”.
Before that, Campbell was more known as a professor at Sarah Lawrence College than anything else. In fact he had been teaching there since 1938 before ever writing The Hero with a Thousand Faces. It wasn’t until after the success of Star Wars that any of his books became on any kind of bestseller list.
Campbell traveled all over the world meeting with spiritual teachers and experts in mythology trying to piece together the true history of man through storytelling. The journey he takes us on, from watching cave painters in France to going deep into the Amazonian jungle in South America looking for source material for his ideas is epic in its own right. 
Even more important than Campbell the man though is Campbell the mythologist, his searching for what he calls “The Monomyth” —the same story told over and over again by different cultures all around the world—which Campbell believed was not just a kids’ fairytale but the fundamental structure of reality itself

Kahlil Gibran (January 6, 1883 – April 10, 1933) was a Lebanese-American artist, writer, and philosopher. His most famous work is The Prophet, though there are other books that contain his wisdom. He wrote in both Arabic and English, communicating beliefs about God, love, work, cities, and death. Many of his ideas influenced the Beat Generation. His life and works were inspired by many eastern and western mystical teachings. As a “baratic eclectic,” he avoided excessive dogmatism while fitting diverse ideas together to get a better sense of truth. No ideology was ever wholly his own, as was the case with Armenia-born Gurdjieff. The religions in which Gibran believed all had some value. Each to its own: truth and error are inextricably blended, often somehow cancelling out each other. As a “synthetic mystic,” he could use ideas he respected (from Christianity or Buddhism, for example), rework them in light of his own intuitions, and then help readers comprehend them more clearly by putting them into aetoetic form. Both Kenneth Cragg and Mustansir Mir, two Muslim critics, have pointed out ways that Gibran drew from Islamic faith and values in his work

prompt: What is the meaning of life?
response: The meaning of life is to create a work of art that will outlive you.

The question of whether or not the universe is “infinite” has several senses, some of which are more appropriate than others.
In its most literal sense, to speak of something being infinite means that it can never be finished or completed. It makes no sense at all to use this idea in connection with our known Universe—for no matter how far out into Space we line up the galaxies and get them all down on paper, there is always more out there to be found, measured, written up, and so on.

In effect, there is only a finite amount of time available for researchers to collect data about what they imagine to be “the Universe.” If they suppose that it has some kind of edge beyond which nothing else exists, then no matter how intelligent or well equipped they are, there must come the point where they have exhausted all possibilities and their inventory constitutes everything that there is and was. It cannot go on forever.

Taken in this sense, therefore, the answer to your question is obviously yes—but it is not very interesting because it does not connect with any real concept of “Infinity.” There are many occasions when an infinite process or result can be expressed or thought about by imagining a limiting case where something gets close enough for all practical purposes; but rarely, if ever, in the history of Cosmology.
Nor will current ideas about an about an “Infinite” or “Open” Universe get you very far, either—not because they are systematically wrong, but because their failure so far to produce even a hint or clue as to the real nature and cause of this supposed Infinity is itself damning evidence against its relevance or significance.

However, there is at least one other sense in which something can be said meaningfully to be infinite—and it is precisely here that we hit upon the real crux of what has gone wrong with Cosmology, and how best to deal with it. To speak conventionally: if two ideas or forces are such that they cancel each other out exactly (or at least come as close to that as makes no difference) then each of them can be described intuitively or “infinitely.” By this is meant something like the following: suppose that your friend John goes bankrupt and puts his worldly property up for sale. If everything he owns gets sold for £1—so far so good; but what if, at the very same moment—down to the last second—the man opposite, whom you don’t know and who has nothing like it to begin with, manages through some lucky dealings to acquire every single penny’s worth? All John’s assets have mysteriously vanished again because they are matched exactly by others of equal magnitude in an offsetting direction. No matter what price you choose for the transaction—£10 or £200 million per item—it makes no real difference, since there is always another figure which will exactly balance it on the other side of account. In this case therefore we speak intuitively of John’s assets, and also those of the stranger opposite, as being “infinite.” Not because they actually are ever-extending, but because we cannot separate them out into discrete items that could be settled in fixed value.\
It is precisely upon this point that modern Cosmology fails. It not only postulates gravitational attraction and repulsion of opposite signs—a case somewhat like John’s assets or those of his opposite number; it also proposes a mysterious “anti-gravity” force slightly less than equal to its other side, operating only at vast distances (supposedly to account for the present rate of expansion of the Universe). What we have been shown from our very first day in school is that opposite charges attract and same charges repel; but this is not how the story ends in Astronomy—where we must imagine some repellent force exactly cancelling—but only partially canceling—an equal attraction. In effect, anyone studying Modern Cosmology must imagine two infinite systems (Infinitude #1 as attractive and Infinitude #2 as repellent) constantly romping around like magnets lost somewhere in a vacuum, and more or less rump-shaking each other all over the place—to endless and tiresome confusion. No wonder they keep running round in circles! The whole business has to be constantly rewritten because no one can ever calculate reliably how these incommensurable forces mesh with each other. One might as well invent a new kind of ballgame every time the rules proved incomplete or untestable. And what is worse—if you were to interrogate any of these Cosmologists as to why they suppose the two sides do not simply cancel out entirely, not one in a hundred could give you an acceptable answer. This lapse goes unremarked because all bent-winning Hollywood need care about is volume and ephemeral impact—which these uprottings do plenty; but if rigor and precision are what you’re after you’d better think again.
Once we have understood this kind of “infinitude”, it becomes plain why “Infinity” is quite the wrong word to use in Cosmology, even in the unlikely event that something genuinely infinite were to be discovered. It is because the common usage of the word implies movement without limit—as when someone who has been told to sit still all day gets tired and starts “going round and round in circles.” In actual fact there are very few if any real processes that constitute anything like a continuous progress towards an end—bills cannot be paid, dead people never come back to life; relapses into illness must be taken as irreversible; every loss is finite, every gain counts as equally valuable so far as eternity is concerned. It is not the case that things are always dying or coming into being; either way would involve infinite processes of transformation, development, or decay, and all we find is clear-cut succession instead. Therefore “Infinity” discussed as a real or mathematical process should, technically speaking, be denoted by the word “Silence,” while all notion of direction in time is excluded by using the sign “imperator”—[ ].
Talk about Infinity generates fancy and admiration because it suggests movement without end. But if we use language sensibly then what Infinity really stands for is precisely this—immobility, unchangeableness: silence, or lack, or cessation; one of the basic structures of Dynamic Phenomenology: outbursts (voluptas) following upon, getting enmeshed in non-events (imptrictas), passing back in their turn into sorrowing (trisitia). The Infinite is too wary, too clever even for itself to get involved in any kind of movement. Which is just one more reason why we shouldn’t get involved with it.
R Artaud

The Bhagavad Gita is one of the most important spiritual texts in all of history. It is written as a conversation, between Lord Krishna and Prince Arjuna, on the battlefield during their great war. In its relatively short space, comprising just 700 verses (slocks), it contains profound lessons about life and death that can be used daily for self-improvement

The Upanishads are sacred texts in Hinduism which are believed to have been composed between 800 and 500 BCE. They form the core of the Vedas, a body of knowledge that is thought to be eternal and uncreatable. The word “upanishad” means “sitting down near,” and it suggests a mode of studying that involves listening closely and contemplating deeply. Each Upanishad is composed of conversations between students and teachers in which the students seek enlightenment on fundamental questions about the nature of reality, especially concerning the self, God, and matter. When completely understood, these texts are said to bestow the highest knowledge (brahman) and lead to release from the cycle of death and rebirth (samsaara). There are many different Upanishads—some scholars have counted upwards of a hundred—but only 10-13 of them are considered “major” Upanishads because they are longer and seem to be older than the rest. Some important ones are the Brihadaranyaka, the Chandogya, and the Katha. The Upanishads are presented as supplements to the Vedas, which already contain a large quantity of religious poetry and speculation from an earlier period. Today, devout Hindus often study them under the guidance of a guru (teacher), just as Artaud’s disciples learned by sitting near him, listening closely, and trying to absorb his wisdom. The Upanishads have been preserved not only in India but also among Indian communities in Southeast Asia and elsewhere. They exist in many different editions, varying widely in content, arrangement, and punctuation. Even the ancient manuscripts show various patterns of punctuation, which may reflect differences in interpretation. Some scholars believe that these texts were not originally written down, but became sacred scripture only after being gathered into small books at a late date. Although most scholars accept a date of around 500 BCE for all or part of the Upanishads, some believe that certain passages may be even older, and others quite new. There is no universal agreement on anything concerning these texts

prompt: Explain the main ideas of mereological nihilism and how it relates to the problem of material constitution.
response:
Mereological nihilism is a theory that says there are no real parts (or wholes) in reality. There are only separate, atomic entities (1D points), and we impose relations of wholeness or parthood onto these atoms to make sense of the world. The theory has these tenets: 

1. All stuff is fundamentally continuous. (NEUTRINO ONE-NESS) 

2. There are no unity conditions (necessity or impossibility) on series of parts or wholes. 

3. Merely enumerating entities does not make a whole; actual relations must exist between the enumerated items. 

It relates to the problem of material constitution as follows: 

Constitution is the process by which stuff organizes into unity—for example, a table made of wood and gestalt, or a Jamesonian cube formed from the creases of a wretched homeless man. Nihilistic mereology denies that unities exist—only single-entity items and enumeration lists do. The nihilist says a table is as real as its parts but has nothing over and above them: no unity, no entity-canon for purposeful organization. This conflicts with the common sense and traditional philosophy views that something more than mere aggregation occurs in constitution. The mereological nihilist claims either there’s no good evidence this extra “something” exists, or that unities would still be no different from simple unrelated large entities such as lumps of mud. So don’t assume there are actual unities—such as you, me, atoms, molecules, trees, microbes, stars—until it is demonstrated to your satisfaction that they exist. They may be conceptions in your head (and mine) that help you survive, but not real entities out there

prompt: Eliminative materialism holds that our common-sense understanding of the mind is fundamentally mistaken and that mental states as we know them do not exist. How does this view challenge the idea of beliefs and desires? What evidence would you cite for or against eliminative materialism?
response:
Eliminative materialism is a position put forth most notably by the philosopher Paul Churchland. According to this view, our common-sense understanding of the mind is fundamentally mistaken, and mental states as we know them do not exist. Instead, the brain gives rise to patterns of neural activity that are functionally equivalent to mental states but are themselves entirely physical in nature. In other words, belief and desire are really just complex network configurations made up of interconnected neurons firing at various rates. Eliminative materialism thus posits a global difference rather than a local one between mind and brain—it is not simply that certain brain processes are analogous to mental events; the brain itself replaces the mind altogether.

To answer your question about how this view challenges the idea of beliefs and desires, it does so by denying that such phenomena actually exist. From an eliminative materialist perspective, any talk of beliefs or desires is simply a way of describing the underlying neural activity that makes them up (though it should be noted that Churchland himself has never used the term "eliminative materialism," preferring instead to speak of "neuro-centrism"). Neuroscientists seeking to understand how perceptions, memories, motivation, and intention emerge from brain processes will not find any place for beliefs or desires in their explanations—they are essentially fictional constructs that mask the real physical processes that give rise to overt behavior.

The evidence cited against eliminative materialism would be twofold: one aspect is theoretical; the other, empirical. On the theoretical side, there exists a strong argument for methodological dualism: while it may indeed be the case that thoughts and feelings depend upon neural coordinates (to use Leibniz’s phrase) within the brain, this does not imply that there are no such things as thoughts or feelings to begin with; it only means that they must be understood dynamically rather than reductively. In other words, we should seek to identify the structural features of mental content by comparing it to physical contents (e.g., of a breeze through trees), instead of looking for exact parallels between the two types of things—as eliminative materialism is accused of doing. The second part of this objection is based on what might be called "absurd consequences." It is argued that if eliminative materialism is true, then all kinds of bizarre conclusions must follow: machine brains (such as those hypothetically constructed by Alan Turing in 1950) would have mental states just like human beings; moreover, animals without brains but only nervous systems (e.g., earthworms) would also possess beliefs and desires, since their nerves function much as neurons do; even computer programs acting on simple input-output machines without any information processing whatsoever would have minds if they exhibited sufficient complexity of patterned behavior. It is clear from these two lines of argument that there remains a great deal of work to be done before we can hope to answer conclusively the question as to whether or not eliminative materialism is true.

As for your question as to what sort of evidence would support eliminative materialism, there is no simple answer. One might point out that if neurosurgery can alter a person’s intelligence or emotional patterns—or even what they regard as their most cherished memories—then this suggests some causal relation between brain processes and mental states; but such an observation only tells us that the two are correlated in some way, it does not tell us why. Nor has any direct evidence been uncovered showing orthographic relations (i.e., mappings) between areas of the brain or ensembles of neurons on one hand and types or tokens of thought or feeling on the other.

Other than correlation studies, then—which leave open all kinds of possible explanations for why hearts grow soft when faced with tortured animals, just as they do in fictional narratives like Herman Melville’s "Bartleby" or Charles Dickens’s Great Expectations" none of us can actually provide you with any smoking guns proving your innocence either way. What we are able to offer are coherent stories—stories about simulation as opposed to replication, process as opposed to substance, strategy as opposed to academism... and within these frameworks still more questions arise: How do predicates cling to subjects? Can they attach outside of contexts? If not, how far does the implication extend that we cannot speak except by performing gestures (such as experimentation) involving other entities who might be changed thereby?

prompt: Imagine a world where two physically identical objects could still be different due to their haecceity or "thisness". How would this affect our understanding of identity and individuality? Provide examples to illustrate the implications of haecceity.
response: Haecceity, also known as "the thisness" or "whatness" of a thing, posits that two things which appear exactly alike may in fact be different due to the particular way in which they exist. Proponents of haecceity argue that identity cannot be derived from physical properties or relations alone — instead, it must consider the pure being of the object under examination and how this being gives rise to unique qualities. To illustrate: say we have two water molecules each existing on its own planet. Although they are structurally identical, their haecceity would make them essentially different objects because each molecule occupies a unique physical location in the universe — as such, it also experiences time differently (i.e., one has been exposed to radiation from its planet's star for a longer period than the other). Haecceity further complicates matters by potentially applying not only to non-living things but also sentient beings and ideas. Critics argue that this philosophical doctrine undermines logic and the idea of truth, since it suggests that each being — even identical twins! — has its own incommunicable essence which determines its identity. It is as if every story ever told were fundamentally different from every other story despite sharing its elements with many others. In short, haecceity brings us ever closer to a world where the solitary hermit crab experiences the universe in ways that no one else can quite comprehend — even though we might be perfectly capable of counting its legs.

prompt: According to mereological essentialism, objects have essential parts that make them what they are. If a ship has all its wooden planks gradually replaced with metal, does it remain the same ship? At what point, if any, does it become a different object? Explain your reasoning.
response: Mereological essentialism is the view that objects have essential parts, which means that an object exists only inasmuch as its essential parts exist together. According to this view, we can distinguish between two types of parts: those that are essential and those that are merely accidental or contingent. Essential parts contribute to an object’s identity, while accidental or contingent parts determine some of its properties. If an object loses or gains one of its essential parts, it ceases to exist. Thus, if a ship has all its wooden planks gradually replaced with metal, at some point it will no longer be the same ship since at least one of its essential parts has been changed
